DOC.HEAD: Some Grand Marnier Mechanical Ads Fail To Operate
With PM-Reader's Digest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Importers of Grand Marnier liqueur say the failure of about 10 percent of the 200,000 motorized holiday advertisements they placed in The New Yorker magazine earlier this month doesn't discourage them. Michel Roux, president of Carillon Importers Ltd. of Teaneck, N.J., called the failure rate ``normal when introducing new technology'' and said he remained committed to trying new approaches to magazine ads. He estimated there have been about 500 complaints from readers who were disappointed that the highly-touted ad didn't work as they thought it should. The ad shows two birds with opposite ends of a ribbon in their beaks. The ribbon is draped around a liqueur bottle and as the birds alternately appear to fly higher, the bottle beneath them swings as if it were a bell. Roux said Monday in a telephone interview that reader surveys indicated 10 percent of the ads failed to operate as intended, and that the company was distributing replacements to those who ask for them. ``It's not a serious problem. We have mailed out 500 or so ads to people who said their ad didn't work,'' he said. He said the technology which made use of a battery and wire embedded beneath the pieces of cardboard used for the ad was sensitive and some systems were likely to get crushed in the binding and mailing processes. Some of the ads sent back were in working condition, but the readers apparently didn't wait long enough for the motorized action to begin, Roux said. He said a few people complained that the bell didn't ring _ but the ad was not designed to emit any sound. And other ads simply didn't work. From Roux's perspective, getting a complaint isn't the worst thing that could happen. ``It shows they were interested by the ad,'' he said. Carillon spent about $750,000 on producing and placing the ad in 200,000 issues of the Dec. 11 edition of The New Yorker that were sent to subscribers in California and New York state. The company has tried to make use of advances in technology for other magazine ads in the past, including singing and talking microchips for another of its products, Absolut vodka. Steven Florio, president of The New Yorker, said the magazine got ``about a dozen calls'' about Grand Marnier ads that failed to move. But he said he welcomed the attention that Roux's ads bring to the magazine. ``We hope he does something as innovative next year,'' Florio said.
